dn8:0.2.eng: The Lion’s Roar to the Naked Ascetic Kassapa

dn8:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruññāyaṃ viharati kaṇṇakatthale migadāye.
dn8:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Ujuññā, in the deer park at Kaṇṇakatthala.
dn8:1.2.comm: Ujuññā was a Kosalan town at which King Pasenadi visited the Buddha in MN 90. | “Deer parks” were nature reservations where the animals were safe from hunters.

dn8:1.3.pli: Atha kho acelo kassapo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
dn8:1.3.eng: Then the naked ascetic Kassapa went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
dn8:1.3.comm: Naked ascetics are still found in India today. Some Jains went naked, but if he were a Jain he would have been introduced as such. Kassapa is an ancient clan name of the brahmins, and we meet four naked ascetics named Kassapa in the canon (here, SN 12.17, SN 41.9, and MN 124). They cannot be the same person, for at the end of each account it is said they went forth and attained arahantship.

dn8:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn8:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side and said to the Buddha:

dn8:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, I have heard the following:

dn8:2.2.pli: ‘samaṇo gotamo sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahati, sabbaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosati upavadatī’ti.
dn8:2.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama criticizes all fervent mortification. He categorically condemns and denounces all fervent mortifiers who live rough.’
dn8:2.2.comm: In his first sermon, the Buddha rejected extremes of self-mortification. There the term was attakilamatha (“self-mortification”), whereas here it is tapas (“heat, burning, fervor”). These refer to the same practices, but tapas points to the fervent ardor of the practitioner, generating an inner heat that “burns off” the corrupting traces of kamma and defilements. This topic is also discussed in AN 10.94.

dn8:2.3.pli: Ye te, bho gotama, evamāhaṃsu: ‘samaṇo gotamo sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahati, sabbaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosati upavadatī’ti, kacci te bhoto gotamassa vuttavādino, na ca bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhanti, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākaronti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchati?
dn8:2.3.eng: Do those who say this repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?

dn8:2.4.eng: For we don’t want to misrepresent the worthy Gotama.”

dn8:3.1.pli: “Ye te, kassapa, evamāhaṃsu: ‘samaṇo gotamo sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahati, sabbaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosati upavadatī’ti, na me te vuttavādino, abbhācikkhanti ca pana maṃ te asatā abhūtena.
dn8:3.1.eng: “Kassapa, those who say this do not repeat what I have said. They misrepresent me with what is false, baseless, and untrue.

dn8:3.2.pli: Idhāhaṃ, kassapa, ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannaṃ.
dn8:3.2.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see some fervent mortifier who lives rough reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

dn8:3.3.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, kassapa, ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ.
dn8:3.3.eng: But I see another fervent mortifier who lives rough reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
dn8:3.3.comm: While the self-mortification itself may be useless, the person who practices it may have other good qualities. The Buddha is cautioning against rash judgement.

dn8:3.4.pli: Idhāhaṃ, kassapa, ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ appadukkhavihāriṃ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannaṃ.
dn8:3.4.eng: I see some fervent mortifier who takes it easy reborn in a place of loss.

dn8:3.5.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, kassapa, ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ appadukkhavihāriṃ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ.
dn8:3.5.eng: But I see another fervent mortifier who takes it easy reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn8:3.6.pli: Yohaṃ, kassapa, imesaṃ tapassīnaṃ evaṃ āgatiñca gatiñca cutiñca upapattiñca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmi, sohaṃ kiṃ sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahissāmi, sabbaṃ vā tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosissāmi upavadissāmi?
dn8:3.6.eng: Since I truly understand the coming and going, passing away and rebirth of these fervent mortifiers in this way, how could I criticize all forms of mortification, or categorically condemn and denounce those fervent mortifiers who live rough?

dn8:4.1.pli: Santi, kassapa, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā paṇḍitā nipuṇā kataparappavādā vālavedhirūpā. Te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni.
dn8:4.1.eng: There are some clever ascetics and brahmins who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. You’d think they live to demolish convictions with their intellect.

dn8:4.2.pli: Tehipi me saddhiṃ ekaccesu ṭhānesu sameti, ekaccesu ṭhānesu na sameti.
dn8:4.2.eng: They agree with me in some matters and disagree in others.

dn8:4.3.pli: Yaṃ te ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘sādhū’ti, mayampi taṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘sādhū’ti.
dn8:4.3.eng: Some of the things that they applaud, I also applaud.

dn8:4.4.pli: Yaṃ te ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘na sādhū’ti, mayampi taṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘na sādhū’ti.
dn8:4.4.eng: Some of the things that they don’t applaud, I also don’t applaud.

dn8:4.5.pli: Yaṃ te ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘sādhū’ti, mayaṃ taṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘na sādhū’ti.
dn8:4.5.eng: But some of the things that they applaud, I don’t applaud.

dn8:4.6.pli: Yaṃ te ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘na sādhū’ti, mayaṃ taṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘sādhū’ti.
dn8:4.6.eng: And some of the things that they don’t applaud, I do applaud.

dn8:4.7.pli: Yaṃ mayaṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘sādhū’ti, parepi taṃ ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘sādhū’ti.
dn8:4.7.eng: Some of the things that I applaud, others also applaud.

dn8:4.8.pli: Yaṃ mayaṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘na sādhū’ti, parepi taṃ ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘na sādhū’ti.
dn8:4.8.eng: Some of the things that I don’t applaud, they also don’t applaud.

dn8:4.9.pli: Yaṃ mayaṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘na sādhū’ti, pare taṃ ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘sādhū’ti.
dn8:4.9.eng: But some of the things that I don’t applaud, others do applaud.

dn8:4.10.pli: Yaṃ mayaṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘sādhū’ti, pare taṃ ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘na sādhū’ti.
dn8:4.10.eng: And some of the things that I do applaud, others don’t applaud.

dn8:5.1.eng: I go up to them and say:

dn8:5.2.pli: ‘yesu no, āvuso, ṭhānesu na sameti, tiṭṭhantu tāni ṭhānāni.
dn8:5.2.eng: ‘Let us leave aside those matters on which we disagree.
dn8:5.2.comm: Again we see the Buddha’s preferred method of establishing common ground first, then building an argument from there.

dn8:5.3.pli: Yesu ṭhānesu sameti, tattha viññū samanuyuñjantaṃ samanugāhantaṃ samanubhāsantaṃ satthārā vā satthāraṃ saṅghena vā saṅghaṃ:
dn8:5.3.eng: But there are some matters on which we agree. Regarding these, sensible people, pursuing, pressing, and grilling, would compare teacher with teacher or community with community:

dn8:5.4.pli: “ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā, sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā, asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā, na alamariyā na alamariyasaṅkhātā, kaṇhā kaṇhasaṅkhātā.
dn8:5.4.eng: “There are things that are unskillful, blameworthy, not to be cultivated, unworthy of the noble ones, and dark—and are reckoned as such.

dn8:5.5.pli: Ko ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, samaṇo vā gotamo, pare vā pana bhonto gaṇācariyā”ti?
dn8:5.5.eng: Who proceeds having totally given these things up: the ascetic Gotama, or the tutors of other communities?”’
dn8:5.5.comm: Rather than logical hair-splitting, the Buddha recommends looking at a person’s conduct.

dn8:6.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
dn8:6.1.eng: It’s possible that they might say:

dn8:6.2.pli: ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā, sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā, asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā, na alamariyā na alamariyasaṅkhātā, kaṇhā kaṇhasaṅkhātā.

dn8:6.3.pli: Samaṇo gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyā’ti.
dn8:6.3.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama proceeds having totally given those unskillful things up, compared with the tutors of other communities.’

dn8:6.4.pli: Itiha, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyuṃ.
dn8:6.4.eng: And that’s how, when sensible people pursue the matter, they will mostly praise us.

dn8:7.1.pli: Aparampi no, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantaṃ samanugāhantaṃ samanubhāsantaṃ satthārā vā satthāraṃ saṅghena vā saṅghaṃ:
dn8:7.1.eng: In addition, sensible people, pursuing, pressing, and grilling, would compare teacher with teacher or community with community:

dn8:7.2.pli: ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā, anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā, sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā, alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā.
dn8:7.2.eng: ‘There are things that are skillful, blameless, worth cultivating, worthy of the noble ones, and bright—and are reckoned as such.

dn8:7.3.pli: Ko ime dhamme anavasesaṃ samādāya vattati, samaṇo vā gotamo, pare vā pana bhonto gaṇācariyā’ti?
dn8:7.3.eng: Who proceeds having totally undertaken these things: the ascetic Gotama, or the tutors of other communities?’

dn8:8.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
dn8:8.1.eng: It’s possible that they might say:

dn8:8.2.pli: ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā, anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā, sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā, alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā.

dn8:8.3.pli: Samaṇo gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaṃ samādāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyā’ti.
dn8:8.3.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama proceeds having totally undertaken these things, compared with the tutors of other communities.’

dn8:8.4.pli: Itiha, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyuṃ.
dn8:8.4.eng: And that’s how, when sensible people pursue the matter, they will mostly praise us.

dn8:9.1.pli: Aparampi no, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantaṃ samanugāhantaṃ samanubhāsantaṃ satthārā vā satthāraṃ saṅghena vā saṅghaṃ:
dn8:9.1.eng: In addition, sensible people, pursuing, pressing, and grilling, would compare teacher with teacher or community with community:

dn8:9.2.pli: ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā, sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā, asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā, na alamariyā na alamariyasaṅkhātā, kaṇhā kaṇhasaṅkhātā.
dn8:9.2.eng: ‘There are things that are unskillful, blameworthy, not to be cultivated, unworthy of the noble ones, and dark—and are reckoned as such.

dn8:9.3.pli: Ko ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, gotamasāvakasaṅgho vā, pare vā pana bhonto gaṇācariyasāvakasaṅghā’ti?
dn8:9.3.eng: Who proceeds having totally given these things up: the ascetic Gotama’s disciples, or the disciples of other tutors?’

dn8:10.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
dn8:10.1.eng: It’s possible that they might say:

dn8:10.2.pli: ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā, sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā, asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā, na alamariyā na alamariyasaṅkhātā, kaṇhā kaṇhasaṅkhātā.

dn8:10.3.pli: Gotamasāvakasaṅgho ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyasāvakasaṅghā’ti.
dn8:10.3.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama’s disciples proceed having totally given those unskillful things up, compared with the disciples of other tutors.’

dn8:10.4.pli: Itiha, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyuṃ.
dn8:10.4.eng: And that’s how, when sensible people pursue the matter, they will mostly praise us.

dn8:11.1.pli: Aparampi no, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantaṃ samanugāhantaṃ samanubhāsantaṃ satthārā vā satthāraṃ saṅghena vā saṅghaṃ.
dn8:11.1.eng: In addition, sensible people, pursuing, pressing, and grilling, would compare teacher with teacher or community with community:

dn8:11.2.pli: ‘Ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā, anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā, sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā, alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā.
dn8:11.2.eng: ‘There are things that are skillful, blameless, worth cultivating, worthy of the noble ones, and bright—and are reckoned as such.

dn8:11.3.pli: Ko ime dhamme anavasesaṃ samādāya vattati, gotamasāvakasaṅgho vā, pare vā pana bhonto gaṇācariyasāvakasaṅghā’ti?
dn8:11.3.eng: Who proceeds having totally undertaken these things: the ascetic Gotama’s disciples, or the disciples of other tutors?’

dn8:12.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
dn8:12.1.eng: It’s possible that they might say:

dn8:12.2.pli: ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā, anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā, sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā, alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā.

dn8:12.3.pli: Gotamasāvakasaṅgho ime dhamme anavasesaṃ samādāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyasāvakasaṅghā’ti.
dn8:12.3.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama’s disciples proceed having totally undertaken those skillful things, compared with the disciples of other tutors.’

dn8:12.4.pli: Itiha, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyuṃ.
dn8:12.4.eng: And that’s how, when sensible people pursue the matter, they will mostly praise us.

dn8:13.1.pli: Atthi, kassapa, maggo atthi paṭipadā, yathāpaṭipanno sāmaññeva ñassati sāmaṃ dakkhati:
dn8:13.1.eng: There is, Kassapa, a path, there is a practice, practicing in accordance with which you will know and see for yourself:

dn8:13.2.pli: ‘samaṇova gotamo kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī’ti.
dn8:13.2.eng: ‘Only the ascetic Gotama’s words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training.’
dn8:13.2.comm: Here -va has an exclusive sense (= eva). Compare Dhp 274: eseva maggo natthañño (“This is the path, there is no other”).

dn8:13.3.pli: Katamo ca, kassapa, maggo, katamā ca paṭipadā, yathāpaṭipanno sāmaññeva ñassati sāmaṃ dakkhati:

dn8:13.4.pli: ‘samaṇova gotamo kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī’ti?

dn8:13.5.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

dn8:13.6.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi.
dn8:13.6.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

dn8:13.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, kassapa, maggo, ayaṃ paṭipadā, yathāpaṭipanno sāmaññeva ñassati sāmaṃ dakkhati ‘samaṇova gotamo kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī’”ti.
dn8:13.7.eng: This is the path, this is the practice, practicing in accordance with which you will know and see for yourself: ‘Only the ascetic Gotama’s words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training.’”

dn8:14.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn8:14.1.eng: When he had spoken, Kassapa said to the Buddha:

dn8:14.2.pli: “imepi kho, āvuso gotama, tapopakkamā etesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sāmaññasaṅkhātā ca brahmaññasaṅkhātā ca.
dn8:14.2.eng: “Reverend Gotama, those ascetics and brahmins consider these courses of fervent mortification to be what makes someone a true ascetic or brahmin.
dn8:14.2.comm: What follows is a description of ascetic practices undertaken by the Jains and similar groups. | The phrase “course of fervent mortification” (tapopakkama) is unique to this sutta. Pakkama means “stepping out”.

dn8:14.3.pli: Acelako hoti, muttācāro, hatthāpalekhano, naehibhaddantiko, natiṭṭhabhaddantiko, nābhihaṭaṃ, na uddissakataṃ, na nimantanaṃ sādiyati.
dn8:14.3.eng: They go naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
dn8:14.3.comm: Buddhist mendicants may not receive food in their hands, nor lick them while eating. Followers of the practices listed here would have walked steadily and randomly for alms, accepting only what was given at the time.

dn8:14.4.pli: So na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na eḷakamantaraṃ, na daṇḍamantaraṃ, na musalamantaraṃ, na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ, na gabbhiniyā, na pāyamānāya, na purisantaragatāya, na saṅkittīsu, na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti, na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī, na macchaṃ, na maṃsaṃ, na suraṃ, na merayaṃ, na thusodakaṃ pivati.
dn8:14.4.eng: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
dn8:14.4.comm: Keeping sheep (eḷaka, for slaughter) goes against the Jain principle of non-violence, as does keeping weapons (daṇḍa). | A musala often means “pestle”, but it can also be a “shovel”; at MN 81:18.12 it is regarded as a virtue to not use one to dig the soil (which is regarded as being alive in Jainism). | Thusodaka is an alcoholic porridge fermented from grain-husks, mentioned alongside sovīraka in the Pali commentaries and Carakasaṁhitā 27g.191.

dn8:14.5.pli: So ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko … sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko;
dn8:14.5.eng: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.

dn8:14.6.pli: ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti … sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti;
dn8:14.6.eng: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.

dn8:14.7.pli: ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, dvīhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti … sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti. Iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
dn8:14.7.eng: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.

dn8:14.8.pli: Imepi kho, āvuso gotama, tapopakkamā etesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sāmaññasaṅkhātā ca brahmaññasaṅkhātā ca.
dn8:14.8.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins also consider these courses of fervent mortification to be what makes someone a true ascetic or brahmin.

dn8:14.9.pli: Sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.
dn8:14.9.eng: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
dn8:14.9.comm: It is not easy to meaningfully distinguish the various kinds of grain.

dn8:14.10.pli: Imepi kho, āvuso gotama, tapopakkamā etesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sāmaññasaṅkhātā ca brahmaññasaṅkhātā ca.
dn8:14.10.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins also consider these courses of fervent mortification to be what makes someone a true ascetic or brahmin.

dn8:14.11.pli: Sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṃsukūlānipi dhāreti, tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti, vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi dhāreti, ulūkapakkhikampi dhāreti,
dn8:14.11.eng: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
dn8:14.11.comm: All are extremely uncomfortable. Christian ascetics wore a “hair shirt” in order to “mortify the flesh” .

dn8:14.12.eng: They tear out hair and beard, committed to this practice.
dn8:14.12.comm: Jain ascetics tear out their hair at ordination, rather than shaving.

dn8:14.13.eng: They constantly stand, turning down seats.
dn8:14.13.comm: Remaining in one posture for months or years at a time is one of the most difficult practices.

dn8:14.14.eng: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.

dn8:14.15.eng: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.

dn8:14.16.eng: They make their bed on a plank, or the bare ground.

dn8:14.17.eng: They lie only on one side.

dn8:14.18.comm: Strict Jain ascetics did not bathe.

dn8:14.19.eng: They stay in the open air.

dn8:14.20.eng: They sleep wherever they lay their mat.

dn8:14.21.eng: They eat unnatural things, committed to the practice of eating unnatural foods.
dn8:14.21.comm: At Kd 6:14.6.3 the four “great unnaturals” (or “filthy edibles”, mahāvikaṭa) are said to be feces, urine, ash, and clay. At MN 12:49.3 the Buddha said he ate the “unnatural things” of feces and urine when undertaking ascetic practices.

dn8:14.22.eng: They don’t drink, committed to the practice of not drinking liquids.

dn8:14.23.eng: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.”
dn8:14.23.comm: This seems out of place here. It was a Brahmanical practice (SN 7.21), as the Jains refused to bathe at all. Indeed, bathing three times a day in the Indian climate would, for most of the year, be quite pleasant.

dn8:15.1.pli: “Acelako cepi, kassapa, hoti, muttācāro, hatthāpalekhano …pe… iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
dn8:15.1.eng: “Kassapa, someone may practice all those forms of mortification,

dn8:15.2.pli: Tassa cāyaṃ sīlasampadā cittasampadā paññāsampadā abhāvitā hoti asacchikatā. Atha kho so ārakāva sāmaññā ārakāva brahmaññā.
dn8:15.2.eng: but if they haven’t developed and realized any accomplishment in ethics, mind, and wisdom, they are far from being a true ascetic or brahmin.
dn8:15.2.comm: The term “accomplishment in mind” (cittasampadā) is equivalent to “accomplishment in immersion” (samādhisampadā). More generally, when citta is used in the context of meditation, it is normally a synonym of samādhi.

dn8:15.3.pli: Yato kho, kassapa, bhikkhu averaṃ abyāpajjaṃ mettacittaṃ bhāveti, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
dn8:15.3.eng: But take a mendicant who develops a heart of love, free of enmity and ill will. And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
dn8:15.3.comm: Mettā is universal love and good will free from attachment. As well as being a foundation for good character and healthy emotional development, it serves to lead the mind into deep meditation of jhāna.

dn8:15.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaṇo itipi brāhmaṇo itipi.
dn8:15.4.eng: When they achieve this, they’re a mendicant who is called a ‘true ascetic’ and also ‘a true brahmin’. …”

dn8:15.5.pli: Sākabhakkho cepi, kassapa, hoti, sāmākabhakkho …pe… vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.

dn8:15.6.pli: Tassa cāyaṃ sīlasampadā cittasampadā paññāsampadā abhāvitā hoti asacchikatā.

dn8:15.7.pli: Atha kho so ārakāva sāmaññā ārakāva brahmaññā.

dn8:15.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaṇo itipi brāhmaṇo itipi.

dn8:15.10.pli: Sāṇāni cepi, kassapa, dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti …pe…

dn8:16.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn8:16.1.eng: When he had spoken, Kassapa said to the Buddha,

dn8:16.2.eng: “It’s hard, worthy Gotama, to be a true ascetic or a true brahmin.”

dn8:16.3.pli: “Pakati kho esā, kassapa, lokasmiṃ ‘dukkaraṃ sāmaññaṃ dukkaraṃ brahmaññan’ti.

dn8:16.4.eng: But someone might practice all those forms of mortification.

dn8:16.5.eng: And if it was only because of just that much, only because of that course of fervent mortification that it was so very hard to be a true ascetic or brahmin, it wouldn’t be appropriate to say that

dn8:16.6.eng: it’s hard to be a true ascetic or brahmin.

dn8:16.7.eng: For it would be quite possible for a householder or a householder’s child—or even the bonded maid who carries the water-jar—

dn8:18.0.eng: 5. The Accomplishment of Ethics, Mind, and Wisdom

dn8:18.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn8:18.1.eng: When he had spoken, Kassapa said to the Buddha,

dn8:18.2.pli: “katamā pana sā, bho gotama, sīlasampadā, katamā cittasampadā, katamā paññāsampadā”ti?
dn8:18.2.eng: “But worthy Gotama, what is that accomplishment in ethics, in mind, and in wisdom?”
dn8:18.2.comm: Note that the heading for this section in the Mahāsaṅgīti edition uses samādhi rather than citta. Headings were added by later editors, and are not part of the original text.

dn8:18.3.pli: “Idha, kassapa, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ, sammāsambuddho …pe…
dn8:18.3.eng: “It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …

dn8:18.4.pli: bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena parisuddhājīvo sīlasampanno indriyesu guttadvāro satisampajaññena samannāgato santuṭṭho.
dn8:18.4.eng: Seeing danger in the slightest fault, a mendicant keeps the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.

dn8:18.5.eng: And how is a mendicant accomplished in ethics?

dn8:18.6.pli: Idha, kassapa, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
dn8:18.6.eng: It’s when a mendicant gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.

dn8:18.7.eng: This pertains to their accomplishment in ethics. …

dn8:19.1.pli: Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti.
dn8:19.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood. …

dn8:19.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti.
dn8:19.3.eng: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.

dn8:19.4.eng: This pertains to their accomplishment in ethics.

dn8:19.5.pli: Sa kho so, kassapa, bhikkhu evaṃ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvarato.
dn8:19.5.eng: A mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.

dn8:19.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, kassapa, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto nihatapaccāmitto na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ paccatthikato;
dn8:19.6.eng: It’s like a king who has defeated his enemies. He sees no danger from his foes in any quarter.

dn8:19.7.pli: evameva kho, kassapa, bhikkhu evaṃ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvarato.
dn8:19.7.eng: In the same way, a mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.

dn8:19.8.pli: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ anavajjasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
dn8:19.8.eng: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

dn8:19.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, kassapa, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti.
dn8:19.9.eng: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics.

dn8:19.10.eng: This, Kassapa, is that accomplishment in ethics. …

dn8:19.11.eng: They enter and remain in the first absorption …

dn8:19.12.eng: This pertains to their accomplishment in mind. …

dn8:19.13.eng: They enter and remain in the second absorption …

dn8:19.16.eng: This pertains to their accomplishment in mind.

dn8:19.17.eng: This, Kassapa, is that accomplishment in mind.

dn8:20.1.eng: When their mind is immersed like this,

dn8:20.2.eng: they project it and extend it toward knowledge and vision …

dn8:20.3.eng: This pertains to their accomplishment in wisdom. …

dn8:20.4.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’

dn8:20.5.eng: This pertains to their accomplishment in wisdom.

dn8:20.6.eng: This, Kassapa, is that accomplishment in wisdom.

dn8:20.7.pli: Imāya ca, kassapa, sīlasampadāya cittasampadāya paññāsampadāya aññā sīlasampadā cittasampadā paññāsampadā uttaritarā vā paṇītatarā vā natthi.
dn8:20.7.eng: And, Kassapa, there is no accomplishment in ethics, mind, and wisdom that is better or finer than this.

dn8:21.1.eng: There are, Kassapa, some ascetics and brahmins who teach ethics.

dn8:21.2.eng: They praise ethical conduct in many ways.

dn8:21.3.pli: Yāvatā, kassapa, ariyaṃ paramaṃ sīlaṃ, nāhaṃ tattha attano samasamaṃ samanupassāmi, kuto bhiyyo.
dn8:21.3.eng: But as far as the highest noble ethics goes, I don’t see anyone who’s my equal, still less my superior.

dn8:21.4.pli: Atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaṃ adhisīlaṃ.
dn8:21.4.eng: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher ethics.
dn8:21.4.comm: This is the ethical practices as described in the Gradual Training.

dn8:21.5.eng: There are, Kassapa, some ascetics and brahmins who teach mortification in disgust of sin.
dn8:21.5.comm: “Mortification in disgust of sin” renders tapojigucchā; tapo is “fervent mortification” and jigucchā is “loathing, disgust”. It captures the severity with which practitioners regarded the “evil” or “sin” with which they were infected, like a quasi-physical stain on the soul, and the burning flame of white-hot pain required to cauterize their spiritual wounds.

dn8:21.6.eng: They praise fervent mortification in disgust of sin in many ways.

dn8:21.7.pli: Yāvatā, kassapa, ariyā paramā tapojigucchā, nāhaṃ tattha attano samasamaṃ samanupassāmi, kuto bhiyyo.
dn8:21.7.eng: But as far as the highest noble fervent mortification in disgust of sin goes, I don’t see anyone who’s my equal, still less my superior.

dn8:21.8.pli: Atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaṃ adhijegucchaṃ.
dn8:21.8.eng: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher disgust of sin.
dn8:21.8.comm: The Buddha repurposes the concept of “disgust of sin”, which here stands in the place of meditation (samādhi).

dn8:21.9.eng: There are, Kassapa, some ascetics and brahmins who teach wisdom.

dn8:21.10.eng: They praise wisdom in many ways.

dn8:21.11.pli: Yāvatā, kassapa, ariyā paramā paññā, nāhaṃ tattha attano samasamaṃ samanupassāmi, kuto bhiyyo.
dn8:21.11.eng: But as far as the highest noble wisdom goes, I don’t see anyone who’s my equal, still less my superior.

dn8:21.12.pli: Atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaṃ adhipaññaṃ.
dn8:21.12.eng: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher wisdom.

dn8:21.13.eng: There are, Kassapa, some ascetics and brahmins who teach freedom.

dn8:21.14.eng: They praise freedom in many ways.

dn8:21.15.pli: Yāvatā, kassapa, ariyā paramā vimutti, nāhaṃ tattha attano samasamaṃ samanupassāmi, kuto bhiyyo.
dn8:21.15.eng: But as far as the highest noble freedom goes, I don’t see anyone who’s my equal, still less my superior.

dn8:21.16.pli: Atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaṃ adhivimutti.
dn8:21.16.eng: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher freedom.

dn8:22.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
dn8:22.1.eng: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:

dn8:22.2.pli: ‘sīhanādaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo nadati, tañca kho suññāgāre nadati, no parisāsū’ti.
dn8:22.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama only roars his lion’s roar in an empty hut, not in an assembly.’
dn8:22.2.comm: A “lion’s roar” is an unapologetic proclamation of spiritual supremacy.

dn8:22.4.pli: ‘Sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadatī’ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanīyā.
dn8:22.4.eng: What should be said is this: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar, and he roars it in the assemblies.’

dn8:22.5.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
dn8:22.5.eng: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:

dn8:22.6.pli: ‘sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadati, no ca kho visārado nadatī’ti.
dn8:22.6.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar, and he roars it in the assemblies. But he doesn’t roar it boldly.’

dn8:22.8.pli: ‘Sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadati, visārado ca nadatī’ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanīyā.
dn8:22.8.eng: What should be said is this: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar, he roars it in the assemblies, and he roars it boldly.’

dn8:22.9.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
dn8:22.9.eng: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:

dn8:22.10.pli: ‘sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadati, visārado ca nadati, no ca kho naṃ pañhaṃ pucchanti …pe…
dn8:22.10.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar, he roars it in the assemblies, and he roars it boldly. But they don’t question him. …

dn8:22.11.pli: pañhañca naṃ pucchanti; no ca kho nesaṃ pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti …pe…
dn8:22.11.eng: Or he doesn’t answer their questions. …

dn8:22.12.pli: pañhañca nesaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti; no ca kho pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheti …pe…
dn8:22.12.eng: Or his answers are not satisfactory. …

dn8:22.13.pli: pañhassa ca veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheti; no ca kho sotabbaṃ maññanti …pe…
dn8:22.13.eng: Or they don’t think him worth listening to. …

dn8:22.14.pli: sotabbañcassa maññanti; no ca kho sutvā pasīdanti …pe…
dn8:22.14.eng: Or they’re not confident after listening. …

dn8:22.15.pli: sutvā cassa pasīdanti; no ca kho pasannākāraṃ karonti …pe…
dn8:22.15.eng: Or they don’t demonstrate their confidence. …

dn8:22.16.pli: pasannākārañca karonti; no ca kho tathattāya paṭipajjanti …pe…

dn8:22.17.pli: tathattāya ca paṭipajjanti; no ca kho paṭipannā ārādhentī’ti.
dn8:22.17.eng: Or they don’t succeed in their practice.’

dn8:22.19.pli: ‘Sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadati, visārado ca nadati, pañhañca naṃ pucchanti, pañhañca nesaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti, pañhassa ca veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheti, sotabbañcassa maññanti, sutvā cassa pasīdanti, pasannākārañca karonti, tathattāya ca paṭipajjanti, paṭipannā ca ārādhentī’ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanīyā.
dn8:22.19.eng: What should be said is this: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar; he roars it in the assemblies; he roars it boldly; they question him; he answers their questions; his answers are satisfactory; they think him worth listening to; they’re confident after listening; they demonstrate their confidence; they practice accordingly; and they succeed in their practice.’

dn8:23.0.eng: 7. The Probation For One Previously Ordained

dn8:23.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, kassapa, samayaṃ rājagahe viharāmi gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
dn8:23.1.eng: Kassapa, this one time I was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

dn8:23.2.pli: Tatra maṃ aññataro tapabrahmacārī nigrodho nāma adhijegucche pañhaṃ apucchi.
dn8:23.2.eng: There a certain fervent celibate named Nigrodha asked me about the higher disgust of sin.
dn8:23.2.comm: The Buddha is referring to the events of the Udumbarikasutta (DN 25). There Nigrodha is referred to as a “wanderer” (paribbājaka) who according to the commentary was clothed. The term tapabrahmacārī here is unique and is not explained in the commentary. I think it means he was a celibate student of a Brahmanical teacher. Tapas and brahmacariya are closely linked in Atharvaveda 11.5.

dn8:23.4.pli: Byākate ca pana me attamano ahosi paraṃ viya mattāyā”ti.
dn8:23.4.eng: He was extremely happy with my answer.”

dn8:23.5.pli: “Ko hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā na attamano assa paraṃ viya mattāya?
dn8:23.5.eng: “Sir, who wouldn’t be extremely happy after hearing the Buddha’s teaching?

dn8:23.6.pli: Ahampi hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā attamano paraṃ viya mattāya.
dn8:23.6.eng: For I too am extremely happy after hearing the Buddha’s teaching!

dn8:23.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
dn8:23.8.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, so too the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

dn8:23.9.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
dn8:23.9.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

dn8:23.10.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
dn8:23.10.eng: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
dn8:23.10.comm: In the early period, there was no distinction between “going forth” (pabbajjā) and “ordination” (upasampadā). They refer to two sides of the same coin: leaving the home life and entering the ascetic life. Ordination was originally granted by the Buddha with the simple call, “Come mendicant!” (Kd 1:6.32.1). As the community grew, the Buddha authorized the Saṅgha to perform the “going forth and ordination” (Kd 1:12.1.1). Later still, the novice (sāmaṇera) platform was introduced for teenagers and became known as “going forth” (Kd 1:54.3.2). Finally, the novice ordination was standardized for all ordinands, even if it was a mere preliminary for the “full ordination”.

dn8:24.1.pli: “Yo kho, kassapa, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṃ, so cattāro māse parivasati, catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya.
dn8:24.1.eng: “Kassapa, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.
dn8:24.1.comm: This probation is laid down in the Vinaya at Kd 1:38.1.5. The candidate shaves, dons the robes, takes refuge, and asks for probation. They must show good conduct and restraint, diligence in duties, and enthusiasm for the Buddha’s teachings and practice.

dn8:24.2.eng: However, I have recognized individual differences in this matter.”
dn8:24.2.comm: In addition to individual exceptions, there are general exceptions for dreadlocked fire-worshipping ascetics, since they believe in kamma, and for the Buddha’s relatives (Kd 1:38.11.3).

dn8:24.3.pli: “Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhanti pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhanti upasampadaṃ, cattāro māse parivasanti, catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya. Ahaṃ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi, catunnaṃ vassānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu, upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā”ti.
dn8:24.3.eng: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”

dn8:24.4.pli: Alattha kho acelo kassapo bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
dn8:24.4.eng: And the naked ascetic Kassapa received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

dn8:24.5.pli: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā kassapo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto na cirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
dn8:24.5.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Kassapa, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn8:24.6.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
dn8:24.6.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

dn8:24.7.pli: Aññataro kho panāyasmā kassapo arahataṃ ahosīti.
dn8:24.7.eng: And Venerable Kassapa became one of the perfected.
